answer_html: \(\left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 0 2\\ 0 1 3\\ 0 0 2 \end{array}\right]\) we see the other type of indicator for no solution that occurred in part (c).
answer_latex:
$\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1    0    2\\
0    1    3\\
0    0    2
\end{array}\right]$ we see the other type of indicator for no solution that occurred in
{part
(c)}.
hints_html: In order for no solution to occur we require contradictory information such as a variable trying to take on two values.
hints_latex:
In order for no solution to occur we require contradictory information
such as a variable trying to take on two values.
hints_raw: In order for no solution to occur we require contradictory information such as a variable trying to take on two values.
question: B 06 (d)
sols_html:
We have 3 equations in 2 unknowns. We know that if we have \(n\) unknowns then we require \(n\) equations for a unique solution. Therefore, in this case we only need two of the equations to uniquely determine the components of a solution vector x. The only way it will satisfy all three equations is if the third equation happens to be equivalent to one of the other two equations. Since we want no solution, we will require the three equations to produce contradicting information. As an example, take the augmented matrix,

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & 2\\ 0 & 1 & 3\\ 0 & 1 & 5 \end{array}\right].\end{aligned}\]

For a solution vector x, with components \(x_1\) and \(x_2\), the matrix claims

\[\begin{aligned} x_1&=2,\\ x_2&=3,\\ x_2&=5.\end{aligned}\]

Two of the equations are contradicting each other and therefore there is no solution. This matrix is not in reduced row-echelon form because of the last row. If we put it in that form,

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & 2\\ 0 & 1 & 3\\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

we see the other type of indicator for no solution that occurred in part (c).
sols_latex:
We have 3 equations in 2 unknowns. We know that if we have $n$ unknowns
then we require $n$ equations for a unique solution. Therefore, in this
case we only need two of the equations to uniquely determine the
components of a solution vector \textbf{x}. The only way it will satisfy
all three equations is if the third equation happens to be equivalent to
one of the other two equations. Since we want no solution, we will
require the three equations to produce contradicting information. As an
example, take the augmented matrix,

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  2\\
0  &  1  &  3\\
0  &  1  &  5
\end{array}\right].
\end{align*}

For a solution vector \textbf{x}, with components $x_1$ and $x_2$, the
matrix claims

\begin{align*}
x_1&=2,\\
x_2&=3,\\
x_2&=5.
\end{align*}

Two of the equations are contradicting each other and therefore there is
no solution. This matrix is not in reduced row-echelon form because of
the last row. If we put it in that form,

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  2\\
0  &  1  &  3\\
0  &  0  &  2
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

we see the other type of indicator for no solution that occurred in
{part
(c)}.
sols_raw:
We have 3 equations in 2 unknowns.  We know that if we have <math>n</math> unknowns then we require <math>n</math> equations for a unique solution.  Therefore, in this case we only need two of the equations to uniquely determine the components of a solution vector '''x'''.  The only way it will satisfy all three equations is if the third equation happens to be equivalent to one of the other two equations.  Since we want no solution, we will require the three equations to produce contradicting information.  As an example, take the augmented matrix,

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  2\\
0  &  1  &  3\\
0  &  1  &  5
\end{array}\right].
</math>

For a solution vector '''x''', with components <math>x_1</math> and <math>x_2</math>, the matrix claims

:<math>
\begin{align}
x_1&=2,\\
x_2&=3,\\
x_2&=5.
\end{align}
</math>

Two of the equations are contradicting each other and therefore there is no solution.  This matrix is not in reduced row-echelon form because of the last row.  If we put it in that form,

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  2\\
0  &  1  &  3\\
0  &  0  &  2
\end{array}\right]
</math>

we see the other type of indicator for no solution that occurred in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B6_(c)|part (c)]].
statement_html:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a single, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Three equations in two unknowns with no solution.
statement_latex:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a
\emph{single}, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix
of the system.

Three equations in two unknowns with no solution.
statement_raw:
Consider the linear systems described below.  In cases (a)-(d), write a ''single'', possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Three equations in two unknowns with no solution.
